client_profile: A couple looking to buy an apartment in Brussels. Budget ranges from 490,000 to 895,000 EUR. Priorities include cafes, family-friendliness, and access to the EU quarter.
must_have: Proximity to brunch spots and cafes.
red_flags: High noise levels in busy areas.
Potential long commute to the EU quarter.
contradictions: Expats neighborhoods can be higher in price.
Some cafes may not cater to families.
Central locations may result in more noise.

top_districts.name: Ixelles
why: Features vibrant cafes along Flagey Square, perfect for brunch outings.
Family-friendly parks such as Parc Tenbosch enhance community feel.
watch_out: Can experience high noise levels during weekends and events.

top_districts.name: Saint-Gilles
why: Boasts many expat-friendly cafes near Parvis de Saint-Gilles.
Offers great family-friendly amenities like playgrounds and schools.
watch_out: Budget can be stretched due to rising property prices.

top_districts.name: European Quarter
why: Easy access to EU institutions enhances the area's appeal and convenience.
Nearby restaurants offer diverse brunch options for families and expats.
watch_out: Longer commutes during peak office hours might be challenging.

questions_for_agent_landlord: What is the total cost of the purchase?
Are there any building charges or upcoming works?
What is the property condition and inspection history?
What is the expected timeline for negotiations?
Are there any legal compliance issues currently?
next_steps: Review potential listings and shortlist favorites.
Contact real estate agencies for additional support.
clarifying_questions: What specific features are you looking for?
Do you have preferred neighborhoods in mind?
What is your timeline for moving?
